Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: LTREB: Behavioral and demographic responses of migratory birds to climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change projected for northeastern North America in the 21st century is likely to influence the distribution and abundance of migratory songbirds by altering the amount and quality of habitat available to them. Long-term studies of Black-throated Blue Warblers (Dendroica caerulescens) have revealed that climate strongly influences habitat quality in this species. The focus of the present proposal is on how a changing climate will affect the key choices that birds make: where to breed (territory selection), whether to return to a territory in a subsequent year (site fidelity), and how to allocate limited resources into mating and parental care (reproductive effort).

The long-term research proposed complements multiple other studies within the Hubbard Brook Ecosystem Study that focus on ecosystem responses to environmental change. This research will provide numerous opportunities for undergraduate training and education of the general public through lectures, educational materials, international partnerships (e.g., the Smithsonian Migratory Bird Center's Bridging the Americas program) and web-based information. Results will be of critical interest to policy makers and decision makers because of their multiple connections to biodiversity, the health of public lands and the broader interest of the public in birds, especially migratory songbirds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award focused on the behavioral responses of migratory birds to climate change and the demographic effects of those responses.  The study was conducted on bird species inhabiting northern hardwoods forest of the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire. We examined where birds chose to breed (territory selection), whether they stayed on a territory or shifted between seasons (site fidelity), and how they allocated limited resources into mating and parental care (reproductive effort). Our goals were to determine whether observed behavioral and demographic adjustments were adequate to compensate for climate-induced changes in territory quality. To do this, we employed the natural experiment of climate differences over time and space (elevation) while also carrying out a long-term food supplementation experiment. During the past five years, the research conducted under this award resulted in 29 papers published in peer-reviewed journals. Our results for the forest bird community suggest a significant decline in both the number of species and the number of individuals on our long-term study plot (44 years of monitoring).

 

Regarding territory selection, we have shown that our focal study species, black-throated blue warbler (Setophaga caerulescens), uses social information as well as habitat features in selecting a territory, and that this species maintains a phenological match with its environment, breeding earlier in warm springs. This behavior results in a substantially higher probability of double brooding and consequently higher reproductive output. Black-throated blue warbler populations may therefore benefit from a warming climate, but populations thus far have remained relatively stable, and other results indicate that increased reproductive output may be balanced by increased adult mortality in warmer years.

 

While we found that the majority of individual warblers were site faithful between years, some did seek new territories. We have shown that the primary factors influencing dispersal of black-throated blue warblers are habitat quality and reproductive success, with males more site-faithful than females, suggesting that males and females pursue different dispersal strategies. We anticipate that the food manipulation, still in progress, will reveal the extent to which environmental variability and change affect dispersal strategies in our study species.

 

Last, we have found that our study species adjusted its mating and paternal effort in response to differences in ecological conditions across the climate (elevation) gradient. At higher elevations where it is cooler, the mean proportion of extra-pair young sired per nest was greater than at lower elevations and males sang at a higher rate. To understand these patterns we quantified the relationship between testosterone and individual investments in mating and paternal effort. Results indicated that song rate was positively associated with testosterone levels; however, male provisioning rates were not, suggesting that testosterone may not mediate the trade-off between mating and paternal effort. In addition, males with elevated testosterone levels suffered reduced body condition, which could negatively affect their survival. Thus, resource allocation to mating and paternal behaviors differed across elevations (climates), and some of these differences were reflected in circulating testosterone levels.

In sum, our research has show that individuals and populations of at least some bird species can response flexibly and adaptively to a changing climate.
